answers.answer: I don't think bad of U!!! I'm sorry I can't help. I've never had a baby but I wish you the best and CONGRATS on your baby!!
Try squats. Those worked for many friends of mine

You can try gettin on all fours for half an hour or so at at time, scrubbing the kitchen floor by hand might pass the time? or...when sitting on the couch, sit forward so your knees are lower than your pelvis, other than that and the post above suggestion if she's staying put there's not much you can do. I tried it all with my first as she was back to back and she never moved, labour was absolute agony....it may just work for you though who knows!Good luck
what about getting up early and going to the mall and walking around the whole thing for like an hour or so but it has to be like brisk walking, it worked for my second preg hope it helps!!!

WHY have they scheduled you for a repeat c-section???  Is it merely because you had one last time?  What were the reasons for that c/s?I'm asking this because you DO NOT HAVE to have a repeat cesarean.  LEGALLY YOU CAN REFUSE!!   If there are no extenuating circumstances (like breech presentation etc) that would potentially cause an emergency c-section to be necessary, you do not have to have one.I had a c-section with my first and have FIVE vaginal births since.  Go to Google and type in "the unnecessarian" and "ICAN online" both are great information for cesarean vs. VBAC and can even give you some info on legalities and refusing a c/s if it's not medically necessary.As the others have said...walking, birthing balls (or just an excercise ball), squats, jumping off the curb and walking, walking, walking...sex..those are all very conducive to bringing on labor if things are already in process.

I walked around our plaza (mall) for nearly three hours today and spend most days chasing my 18 month old.The baby is nearly fully engaged as I'm always on my feet cleaning etc.I've also tried Evening Primrose, sex, nipple stimulation, birthing ball etc.And I eat curry all the time lol.I've had two caesars, my first four years ago at 26 weeks and second last year, which is why they want bubs born via caesarean.OB won't give an exact reason, just says its hospital policy to do a third caesarean after two and that due to past complications they want this baby out fast and safe.My last son was a caesar because of preeclampsia and gestational diabetes and being transverse.I'm just upset that despite having a relatively trouble free pregnancy and having had scans on my scar that I'm not being given so much as a chance to deliver naturally.With my son last year, the surgeons gave me four spinals and two locals, failed them all, hit a nerve in my back and then put me under a general. The general did not agree with me, I went into hypertension stage 3 and was in recovery for 6 hours. I wasn't even allowed to see my son.They left placenta in me and left me with a abscess the size of a tennis ball with a staph infection. The issues weren't rectified for months and i am absolutely petrified that something similar will happen this time.But, if doctors think its best my daughter is born at this gestation to avoid complications, I don't want to argue.I want her here healthy and safe :(

I agree w/ GA.  I don't understand why they are making you have one, and so early too.  They can't make you.  Without a medical reason, I just don't understand.As for your question, my personal opinion is that until the baby is ready, you can do all you want, but the baby will come when the baby is ready to come.

It's harder to get doctors and hospitals to agree to a VBAC after two cesareans, especially so close together.  Some hospitals don't allow VBACs, so your doctor might be telling the truth and have no other choice.  Hopefully they'll know your situation when you get there and have a better plan this time as far as the anesthesia goes.Every pregnancy is different.  The reactions to the medication could have been due to your child.  This time you might not have any of those problems.

My neighbor is a nurse on the baby floor. We have discussed that dr's shouldnt push for c-sections just because a prior delivery was a c-section. However, despite her belief in vbacs, she told me it would be foolish and too risky to try vbac after 2 c-sections. I asked why. She said the risk of adhesion from scar tissue is too much, and there is a much greater risk of significant problems that would threaten both mom and baby. This potential is even greater if you have never delivered vaginally.I am a little surprised that they are doing it before 38 weeks. Have they tested for lung maturity or given you steroid shots as a precaution? Sometimes the baby's lungs aren't quite developed yet at that gestation.

We must have been typing at the same time, so I wasn't aware of the 2 previous c-sections.  I don't blame you for being nervous, though, with the problems you had last time.  Whether you are delivering at the same hospital w/ the same doctor or not, I'd speak to the anesthesia dept. now about your options and the problems you had last time.  I would want to know that walking in the door, if it were me.  About options I mean.  I think you will feel better and whoever is in charge of your care, will also be better prepared.I also agree w/ tired,in that, I am surprised how early they are doing it and am def curious if they will give you those steroid shots as a precaution.  The lungs are the last thing to fully develop, so even after 37 weeks, the babies can still possibly have breathing problems.

many hospitals have that "policy".  Here in the small town I live in the hospital doesn't have a policy, per se, but there's an attitude.  They say none of the docs here will allow vbacs therefore they don't do them at the hospital.  And it's true the docs around here won't.  I just happened to have already had 3 vbacs before I saw the ob I go to here so he was a little more willing to let me.  Even though he has NOT let anyone else.  But I put my foot down that I would NOT have an unnecessary cesarean.  The nurse in L &D this last time even went so far as to "prep" me for a c/s by shaving me and giving me attitude about wanting ice chips.  She was SOOO sure I was gonna have one.  I proved her wrong.It's hard to get past this attitude docs and hospitals have.  But the ACOG released less restrictive guidelines on VBAc's last year.  They are now saying that unless there are extenuating circumstances that even a VBAC after TWO c/s is safe.  I even printed out the ACOG guidelines and took them with me to the hospital JUST in case.

They've not given me any ultrasounds or tested Ruby's (baby) lungs at all.I am going to the same hospital but seeing a different OB, I've also seen a senior anaesthetist regarding my concerns about the failed spinals and my reaction to the general. I don't believe that it has anything to do with the baby as I had the same reaction under a general 6 years ago.The anaesthetist basically told me it happens,spinals fail and that's that so we'll what happens.I don't like the idea of having another caesarean or the long recovery especially with an 18 month old but my main concern is avoiding a general.To go to sleep pregnant and wake hours later with your baby gone, vomiting blood and being in excruciating pain is not something I'd wish on any mother, and unfortunately this was my experience.I wasn't able to see my son for around 6 hours and the nurses in recovery wouldn't do so much as tell me where he was or if he was ok.It made the birth of my son one of the most horrific experiences of my life.I don't know where you guys are, I'm in Melbourne, Australia. We have some of the best hospitals in the world so it's upsetting that some of the doctors are so ignorant.The head midwife at the hospital  told me that as the scans they performed of my uterus to inspect the scarring came back quite well, that should I go into labor naturally before the scheduled c-section date that they would do their best to allow me to deliver naturally providing that I understood that this would mean very close monitoring and that she would allow no 'grey area' eitherbubs is happy or not, no in between. She would perform a caesarean at the first sign of distress, which I completely agree with.This is why I'm hoping labor will start naturally. But, a caesar is looking inevitable :(

You poor thing - what a horrible experience... It just shouldn't have to be that way!I also had a c section at one of the big hospitals in melb. Brilliant and personable anaesthetist who seemed to do the spinal effortlessly. Happy to share his details if it's of any help?I recently asked my ob

If I was locked into a c section for next bub (original was due to size). He said no but it would be his preference due to risks of vbac. He talked about the increased risk of uterine rupture in a vbac and that once that happens the maternal death rate is 1 in 4. So whilst I completely understand your fear of another c (doubly so given your past) I would also be nervous about vbac... I think it sounds like you've got a great mid wife, so if you trust her judgement then you will be just fine.

hello - I too have had two c-sections, the first after 8 hours of labor and complications with bubs heart rate and the second elective as I got PND after the first and wanted to know and control all I could with the second.  However this time around I have done my research and changed obgyn and am going for a VBAC2.   My doc is optimistic but very on the ball and has placed a number of stipulations on the process. I have to have a trouble free pregnancy, bubs a small or average size (last two were 6 pound 9 and 6 pound 3) bub in a good position and have a scan of lining and scar at 38 weeks to check it is strong enough to take the contractions and labor.  If all this is good then I can have a trial of labor - meaning no inductions and I have to be progressing well with no problems for him to allow me to continue.  He doesn't really want me to have an epi as it can slow down labor and they can not give pitocin to speed things back up and if things are going well he thinks why do something to change that (I think cause it is going to hurt lol).  Anyway I am currently 33weeks and things are looking really good so far.  No probs with pregnancy, bub looking average size and already has head down and doesn't look like moving back around, placenta high and not in the way and health looking good.  In a few more weeks i will have my scan and that will determine what happens next but I have my fingers crossed I can at least have a trial of labor.  I would talk more to your doc and discuss your fears and concerns and ask why so early and to maybe push the c-section date back another weeks to give yourself more time to go naturally. Good luck and don't be pushed into anything you don't want as that leads to regrets, possible PND etc.  Obviously a healthy bub and mum is the number one goal but talking to your doc is also important.

The risk of uterine rupture in most cases is less than 1-2%.  MANY doctors hype up the risks in order to convince the patient to go for a repeat cesarean.  Even with a VBAC2 the risks are still extremely minimal.

Well, I am really sorry!    I still don't understand why they aren't waiting until you are closer to your due date; especially if they are considering you having a VBAC if you go into labor on your own.  It just doesn't make any sense to me.  I would def ask about the steroid shots though.  Good luck!

If Im not mistaken you ALWAYS can refuse a Csection from your doctor at any hospital. They've got to treat you esp if you go the emergency room at least that's how it is in the United States.Personally I don't want a natural birth. I've had 2 Csections and am OK with a repeat even though recovery was hard with both. I figure that I've already got the scar I shouldn't worry about stretching things with a natural birth (or the pain of waiting to dialate to 4cm before the epidural).I plan to have a repeat Csection for baby #3 whenever we choose to TTC another baby. You should be able to deny a Csection if you REALLY want to try a normal birth. The risk of rupture is relatively small but there is a risk and you have to be aware of that.TTYLCindie
the risk is actually no greater than a women who has had a c-section getting pregnant again in the first place. Good luck and I hope you and your baby stay happy and healthy.

question: Hi Ladies :)I'm currently 36 +5 and scheduled for a c-section this coming Thursday (37+4)...Our little girl has been engaged for two weeks now and I've been having constant pressure and irregular contractions... I'd really like to have our daughter naturally as the last time I had a c-section it was a horror story!I've tried using the birthing ball, and have been using Evening Primrose Oil Capsules since around 30 weeks, I've even tried the breast pump and sex! Nothing is working :(Have any of you guys had success with other methods?I know that MANY readers will disapprove but please keep in mind, I am not making these attempts purely because I'm sick of being pregnant like many do, as I know that my daughter will be here by Thursday regardless., I am doing so to avoid having another 7 MONTH recovery from a c-section like I had with my son.So, please do not reply if you are going to be negative.Thanks :)
title: Desperate To Avoid C-Section :(
